bestBHT.bht: Although the author had many things to convey, they choose not to write them down using ink and a reed pen. This decision, indicated by the use of the imperfect tense, suggests that these thoughts were present at the outset of writing. The mention of a reed pen brings to mind associations with Jesus being mocked with a scepter and the use of a measuring-reed in Revelation. Instead of continuing to write, the author refrains from using traditional means, possibly indicating the availability of alternative methods for communication.

Henry Alford: 13. 14.] Close of the Epistle. 13.] I had many things to write to thee, howbeit I will not to write by means of ink and reed (see on 2 John 12):
Albert Barnes: I had many things to write ...
But I will not with ink and pen ...
Marvin Vincent: I had [ειχον]. The imperfect tense: I was having, when I began to write."
Pen [καλαμου]. Lit., reed. See Matthew 11:7. The staff or scepter placed in mockery in Jesus' hand, Matthew 27:29.
Archibald T. Robertson: I do not wish to go on writing them.
By means of black ink and reed.
Used for papyrus and parchment, as γραφειον (a sharp stilus) for wax tablets.
John Gill: I have many things to write...but I will not with ink and pen write unto thee."
Suggesting he should take another method of communicating his mind to him.

bhtAttempts.bht: Although the author of this verse initially had many things to communicate, he decides against writing them down using traditional means like ink and a reed pen. The imperfect tense of the verb suggests that he had these thoughts when he began writing. The use of the term reed can be seen in other contexts, such as in the scepter mockingly placed in Jesus' hand, or even as a measuring-reed in the book of Revelation. Instead of continuing to write, the author wishes to refrain from further communication through this traditional method. Instead, he may be implying that there are alternative ways to convey his message.

Although the author refrains from using ink and a reed pen to write down the many things they had in mind, it is clear that there was a desire to communicate further. The use of the imperfect tense indicates that these thoughts were present at the beginning of writing. The mention of a reed offers connections to other contexts, such as the mockery of Jesus with a scepter and the use of a measuring-reed in Revelation. By choosing not to continue writing, the author highlights the potential for alternative methods of conveying their message.

Initially intending to write down many things, the author decides against using ink and a reed pen. The imperfect tense suggests these thoughts arose at the beginning of the writing process. The mention of a reed implies connections to other contexts like the mocking scepter and the measuring-reed. Instead of continuing to write, the author opts not to use traditional means, possibly hinting at alternative methods of communication.

Although the author had many things to convey, they choose not to write them down using ink and a reed pen. This decision, indicated by the use of the imperfect tense, suggests that these thoughts were present at the outset of writing. The mention of a reed pen brings to mind associations with Jesus being mocked with a scepter and the use of a measuring-reed in Revelation. Instead of continuing to write, the author refrains from using traditional means, possibly indicating the availability of alternative methods for communication.

Despite having many thoughts to share, the author chooses not to write them down with ink and a reed pen. The imperfect tense signifies that these thoughts were present at the beginning of writing. The mention of a reed pen brings to mind other references such as the mocking scepter and the measuring-reed. Rather than continuing to write, the author opts not to use conventional means, hinting at alternative methods of communication.
